text: Hello! I have a question on reposting content: our CEO has a published article on a digital media platform, and we have a slightly different version of it that we're thinking of posting on our blog. I'm thinking I'll add a line like 'An edited version of this article appeared on X' and publish the blog version. Will Google view it as plagiarism? Will I be inviting SEO trouble? TIA!

text: I’m no expert but I have done this before with partner organisations who want to share our content. They had to add ‘<https://www.semrush.com/blog/canonical-url-guide/|canonical tags>’ to avoid SEO issues. I’ve linked as that’ll do a better job of explaining than me :see_no_evil:

elements.text: Thanks much!

text: Yeah, you’ll want to canonicalize the third-party site to YOUR site so Google gives YOUR owned domain the credit for that piece. If it’s somewhere like Medium, there should be a place to add a canonical URL. Generally, though, the piece that was indexed first gets preference to Google (and other search engines) because it’s in their index and the other can be seen as a copy. There’s no penalty for duplicate content, just potential to cannibalize your own rankings. I’d encourage your CEO to publish on the owned site first before somewhere like Medium.

elements.text: Yeah, you’ll want to canonicalize the third-party site to YOUR site so Google gives YOUR owned domain the credit for that piece. Generally, though, the piece that was indexed first gets preference to Google (and other search engines) because it’s in their index and the other can be seen as a copy. There’s no penalty for duplicate content, just potential to cannibalize your own rankings. I’d encourage your CEO to publish on the owned site first before somewhere like Medium.

text: Hi there! Quick SEO question: when is content seen as duplicate content that would be penalized by Google? Any idea if a page or site would be penalized when 2 pages have a couple paragraphs that are the same? Even if the pages have quite a different structure?

elements.text: Hi there! Quick SEO question: when is content seen as duplicate content that would be penalized by Google? Any idea if a page or site would be penalized when 2 pages have a couple paragraphs that are the same? Even if the pages have quite a different structure?

text: haha I only just realized the question above is quite similar…but this duplicate content would exist on the same URL so using canonical tags would not be relevant right?

elements.text: haha I only just realized the question above is quite similar…but this duplicate content would exist on the same URL so using canonical tags would not be relevant right?

text:
From what I've seen, it's normal to have some duplication, especially for CTAs, landing pages, etc. The only time our clients have had issues is when their content is duplicated on many other websites without canonicalization and it looks like an unnatural pattern.

Yoast automatically creates self-referencing canonical tags. Each page should probably have a canonical, as they <https://yoast.com/rel-canonical/|lay out>. In most cases, the canonical tag will be self-referencing.

I'd probably avoid canonicalizing one page on your site for a bunch of only-similar-pages. The canonical page is the most likely to rank and the others typically pass authority to the canonical.

attachments.title: rel=canonical: the ultimate guide
attachments.text: The canonical URL allows you to tell search engines that certain similar URLs are actually one and the same. Learn how to use rel=canonical!

text: Duplicate content penalties <https://www.contentkingapp.com/academy/duplicate-content/#can-i-get-a-duplicate-content-penalty|are largely a myth from the past>. I wouldn’t worry about reusing a paragraph. And I wouldn’t use a canonical URL here. I’d use that in case you’re like “Hmm, this page doesn’t add any value over this other page. I better canonicalize to the other page then”.

attachments.title: Duplicate Content SEO best practices: how to find and fix it
attachments.text: Learn how to boost your SEO by fixing duplicate content issues.
attachments.fallback: ContentKing: Duplicate Content SEO best practices: how to find and fix it

text: <@U01GLCVCT89> Reading your last comment, I wouldn't be as worried about duplicate content as I would be about cannibalizing yourself! It depends on the situation, but I generally try and stay away from targeting the same set of keywords across multiple pages, because it can be hard for the GoogleBot to decide which page you really want to rank for which keywords.

elements.text: Reading your last comment, I wouldn't be as worried about duplicate content as I would be about cannibalizing yourself! text: You could either redirect or canonicalize the original page to the new landing page. Hmm. That's tricky... honestly, if you hadn't said the other thing about the structure/format, I'd say just to convert the blog post into the landing page. :woman-shrugging::skin-tone-2:

text: <@U01GLCVCT89> I did something similar recently where I took content from a couple disparate blog posts and then reinputted it on a page that had a much higher likelihood of a CVR (I just pulled the plug on the posts and redirected them). I did lose some of that initial traffic, but after about two months I'm seeing it pick back up (with way more conversions, as expected!). It's not always ideal to shoot yourself in the foot, but I did projections and the longterm ROI was much better with the landing page so I went for it.

elements.text: I did something similar recently where I took content from a couple disparate blog posts and then reinputted it on a page that had a much higher likelihood of a CVR (I just pulled the plug on the posts and redirected them). text: Hi all! We just finished a long-awaited content piece where we tried something new (building out an interactive web page instead of the typical PDF download). We built it from repurposed content that we had already sent out via PDF for lead gen. One of our main goals is to gain search traffic from it. We have promoted via social, our website, linked to it on the blog, email. Do you all have any ideas for the best ways to promote it/push it higher in search?

text: Don't optimize the landing page, then. It won't get ranked on accident. :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Do the two pages cater to different search intents (e.g informational vs transactional)? If so, you can keep them separate but it can be tricky because you need to make sure you clearly target the queries and adjust internal link structure too). But it can work for sure. For example, I’ve got a massive guide on robots.txt files which ranks for a ton of terms (top of the funnel, aimed at informing), but created a separate one around monitoring you robots.txt (mid-funnel, aimed to generate leads). Closely related but don’t canibalize because the search intent is different.
